physDesc.p: This letter is three pages long. On the first page, the words “Poetry (Monroe)” are written in pencil at the top. The second and third pages also have, typed, H.M. with the corresponding page number in the top left corner, and the date (1/26/16) in the top right corner. On the last page, there is faint text on the page near the bottom. The text is large and mirrored on the opposite side of the page, perhaps written on the other side? It reads, “BERKSHIRE LINEN U.S.A.”

div.p: I cannot tell you how miserable I was, not being able to go out to Chicago. Mrs. Lathrop&aphos;s very kind invitation came too late for me to avail myself of it. I am enclosing a letter, which I should be very much obliged to you if you would give her.

Mrs. Russell writes that you asked her to the dinner, and I am in hopes that she will tell me all about it.I am enclosing my cheque for $2.50 for her plate, and only regret that it was not more and that I did not have a plate, too. I wrote Mrs. Russell a long screed of questions to ask you, because you have been so busy lately, you Bad Thing, you have not answered anything I have been asking, and I naturally am extremely anxious to know how you are going to represent me in your Anthology. I count a good deal on that Anthology. I think it is going to be a good thing. Fletcher and I have removed ourselves from the "e;Others"e; Anthology, as we did not like their methods, and we did not want people to think they were Imagists. I think Richard Aldington has also taken himself out of it. I do not believe it stands any show to speak of, except as a freak. But that makes your Anthology all the more important to the poets and the public, for this will show the sincere work that is being done, rather than the more shoddy kind.
I imagine you are only going to put into it those poems which have appeared in “Poetry.” I really do want very much to know which of mine you have chosen.

pb.p: I also asked Mrs. Russell to see you and Mrs. Aldis, and find out if there was any chance of my giving any talk or talks in Chicago later in the year, say in March or April. I have been giving a great many lectures here and several in New York, and they have been very successful, and I am extremely anxious to widen my scope and include Chicago. Chicago has always been so nice to me that I do not see why they should not greet my talks as well as New York and Boston have. I suppose Mrs. Russell will have seen you by this time, and will have told you in what the lectures consist. Some of them are talks about the "new poetry"e; with illustrations. In others cases, I have simply been asked to read my own poems. But I won't go into detail now, until I see what Mrs. Russell has said to you.

Meanwhile, here is the poem that I intended to read at your dinner. It is another one of that same series of which "e;Reaping,"e; which you and Mr. Masters like so much, was the first. I want you to publish it. Personally, I think it is the best of that Yankee lot. It is fairly long, I know, but no longer than Hueffer's "e;Heaven,"e; and I think you ought to have it. You always print me two or three times a year, and this, it seems to me, would make a nice Spring contribution. It will appear in my next volume, which is coming out next Autumn, so you have quite a little leeway before you need publish it; but of course, as I have not bee in your magazine since last September, I would kind of like to be in about April, if you can manage it.

My defense of you appears in next month's "e;Poetry Journal,"e; and
I will send you a copy.
You have not answered me about Flint's poems, but I suppose you are printing them that we can use them in the Anthology to be published in April. Do be a Good Girl, and answer this sometime:
I trust your dinner was a great success, and if you will only give another next year, I will take up my abode in Chicago weeks previously, in order to be there.
